column1: San José del Cabo (Spanish pronunciation: [san xo'se ðel 'kaβo]
column2: Saint Joseph of the Cape) is a city located in southern Baja California Sur state
column3: Mexico. It is the seat of Los Cabos Municipality lying at a shallow bay 20 miles (32 km) northeast of Cabo San Lucas on the Gulf of California. The city has a population of 93
column4: 069 as of 2015. San José del Cabo together with Cabo San Lucas are known as Los Cabos. Together they form a metropolitan area of 305
column5: 983 inhabitants.The two cities are served by Los Cabos International Airport.

column3: 069. Together with neighboring Cabo San Lucas
column4: it forms a major tourist destination for travelers
column6: 000 hotel guests in 2011.The Mission San José del Cabo was founded in 1730 on the west bank of the nearby Río San José. The Río San José flows into an estuary
column7: the largest body of fresh water in southern Baja California Sur
column8: after flowing largely underground for 39.1 kilometres (24.3 mi) from its origin in the Sierra de la Laguna (Laguna Mountains). For more than 250 years it has furnished drinking and irrigation water for the town of San Jose del Cabo
column9: beginning as a source of fresh water for Spanish galleons traveling back from the Philippines. The river used to flow above ground until the beginning of the 20th century due to anthropogenic causes. A one km long sand bar separates the estuary from what early Spanish explorers
column11: called the Bahía de San Bernabé or Bay of San Bernabé and now San José del Cabo Bay.San José del Cabo is one of two places where the rare and nearly extinct rice rat Oryzomys peninsulae has been found.

column2: like almost all of the Baja California peninsula
column3: has an arid climate (Köppen BWh) although it does receive more rainfall than most areas further north due to tropical cyclones occasionally coming in from the south and bringing very heavy falls such as 340 millimetres (13.4 in) on the first of September 1998 and 316 millimetres (12.4 in) on 3 November 1993. Overall
column5: rainfall is some of the most erratic anywhere in the world due to this influence
column6: and many years pass by without significant falls at all.

column1: The sea experiences lows of 72–73 °F (22–23 °C) in winter
column2: and highs of 77–84 °F (25–29 °C) during the summer months.
